assessment.title: Chapter 9 Exam - Lists, List Functions, Traversals, Searching

material.mattext: Hiding syntax errors so the program runs faster
Encrypting data to prevent hackers from reading it
Removing every unused variable in the code
Which of the following is a correctly declared Python list?
Which data types may be mixed inside a Python list?

What is the index of "Beagle"?

dogs = ["Poodle", "Collie", "Terrier", "Beagle"]
Which of the following describes a tuple?
Which code accesses the last element of a list named scores?
Which situation best demonstrates why lists are useful?

Given the code below, what is the resulting list?

grades = [90, 80, 70]
grades.insert(1, 85)
What error occurs when calling remove("Blueberry") on a list that does not contain that value?
Which statement about list and tuple methods is true?
append() works on both lists and tuples

What is the result of the following code?

a = [1, 2, 3]
b = a
a[0] = 10
print(b)
What is the correct way to make a separate copy of a list?
What does the in keyword return when used with a list?

What is the output of this code?

nums = [3, 6, 9, 12]
print(max(nums))

What does this loop print?

nums = [2, 4, 6]
for n in nums:
print(n)
Which traversal is best when you need to modify list values?
All even numbers up to and including 10
What is a limitation of using for item in list when traversing?
It cannot iterate over the whole list

Given the loop below, which range expression accesses every other element starting at index 0?

for i in range(???):
print(myList[i])
Which loop prints the list in reverse?

What does this code print?

pets = ["dog", "cat", "fish"]
for i in range(len(pets)):
print(i)
Which traversal is best when you do not need indexes?
In range(start, stop, step), which part is exclusive (never included in the sequence)?
What is the mid index when low = 2 and high = 9?
Binary search efficiency is usually described as:
In binary search, what indicates that the target is not found?
What is the maximum number of iterations for a binary search on 400 elements?
Which search examines every element until it finds the target (or reaches the end)?
In each iteration of a binary search, what is examined?
Which algorithm is usually faster on very large sorted lists?
If midValue is too high during a binary search, what should happen to highIndex?

What does this code print?

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]
nums.pop(1)
nums.append(10)
print(nums)

What does this code print?

colors = ["red", "blue", "green", "yellow"]
for c in colors:
if c == "green":
break
print(c)
red blue green40. What does this code print?

What does this code print?

items = [3, 6, 9, 12]
print(9 in items)
A search that examines every element until the target is found is called a [71de6422f40842d9b699559db6ab8b59].
A data type that cannot be changed after creation is called [d943e6d0d54443a08ab4f21f338738ac].
The keyword used to test whether a value appears inside a list is [520247f2092943e7ad417f4bfbeddcdb].
According to Lesson 1, what happens if you try to access a specific index that is larger than the list contains (e.g., highScores[10] in a list of 5 items)?
A "list assignment index out of range" runtime error occurs
The program creates a new slot at that index automatically
The program wraps around and accesses the beginning of the list
